a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes binomial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "binomial 10 2 * binomial 8 3 = 2520"
shows  "2520 = binomial 10 2 * binomial 8 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{10}{2}\times \dbinom{8}{3}$. The final Answer is 2520
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{10}{2}\times \dbinom{8}{3} &= \dfrac{10!}{2!8! }\times \dfrac{8!}{3!5!} \\ &= \dfrac{10!}{2!3!5!} \\ &= \dfrac{10\times 9\times 8\times 7\times 6}{(2\times 1)\times (3\times 2\times 1)} \\
 &= \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \times 9 \times 8 \times 7 \times \dfrac{6}{3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 5\times 9\times 8\times 7\times 1 \\ &= \boxed{2520}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes binomial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "binomial 10 2 * binomial 8 3 = 2520"
shows  "2520 = binomial 10 2 * binomial 8 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the product of the binomial coefficients $\binom{10}{2}$ and $\binom{8}{3}$. The final answer is $2520$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes binomial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n k. binomial n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "binomial 10 2 * binomial 8 3 = 2520"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{10}{2}\times \dbinom{8}{3}$. The final Answer is 2520
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{10}{2}\times \dbinom{8}{3} &= \dfrac{10!}{2!8! }\times \dfrac{8!}{3!5!} \\ &= \dfrac{10!}{2!3!5!} \\ &= \dfrac{10\times 9\times 8\times 7\times 6}{(2\times 1)\times (3\times 2\times 1)} \\
 &= \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \times 9 \times 8 \times 7 \times \dfrac{6}{3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 5\times 9\times 8\times 7\times 1 \\ &= \boxed{2520}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes binomial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n k. binomial n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "binomial 10 2 * binomial 8 3 = 2520"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: What is the product of the binomial coefficient ${10 \choose 2}$ and ${8 \choose 3}$, given that the binomial coefficient is defined as ${n \choose k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}$. The final answer is 2520.

fixes binomial :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat)"

shows  "binomial 10 2 * binomial 8 3 = 2520"

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCr = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "nCr 10 2 * nCr 8 3 = 2520"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{10}{2}\times \dbinom{8}{3}$. The final Answer is 2520
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{10}{2}\times \dbinom{8}{3} &= \dfrac{10!}{2!8! }\times \dfrac{8!}{3!5!} \\ &= \dfrac{10!}{2!3!5!} \\ &= \dfrac{10\times 9\times 8\times 7\times 6}{(2\times 1)\times (3\times 2\times 1)} \\
 &= \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \times 9 \times 8 \times 7 \times \dfrac{6}{3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 5\times 9\times 8\times 7\times 1 \\ &= \boxed{2520}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCr = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "nCr 10 2 * nCr 8 3 = 2520"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the product of the number of ways to choose 2 items from a set of 10 items and the number of ways to choose 3 items from a set of 8 items. The final answer is 2520.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes binomial :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "binomial = (\<lambda>(n k). fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "binomial (10, 2) * binomial (8, 3) = 2520"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{10}{2}\times \dbinom{8}{3}$. The final Answer is 2520
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{10}{2}\times \dbinom{8}{3} &= \dfrac{10!}{2!8! }\times \dfrac{8!}{3!5!} \\ &= \dfrac{10!}{2!3!5!} \\ &= \dfrac{10\times 9\times 8\times 7\times 6}{(2\times 1)\times (3\times 2\times 1)} \\
 &= \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \times 9 \times 8 \times 7 \times \dfrac{6}{3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 5\times 9\times 8\times 7\times 1 \\ &= \boxed{2520}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes binomial :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "binomial = (\<lambda>(n k). fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "binomial (10, 2) * binomial (8, 3) = 2520"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Calculate the product of the binomial coefficients $\binom{10}{2}$ and $\binom{8}{3}$. The final answer is 2520.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 10 choose 2 * 8 choose 3"
shows  "n = 2520"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{10}{2}\times \dbinom{8}{3}$. The final Answer is 2520
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{10}{2}\times \dbinom{8}{3} &= \dfrac{10!}{2!8! }\times \dfrac{8!}{3!5!} \\ &= \dfrac{10!}{2!3!5!} \\ &= \dfrac{10\times 9\times 8\times 7\times 6}{(2\times 1)\times (3\times 2\times 1)} \\
 &= \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \times 9 \times 8 \times 7 \times \dfrac{6}{3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 5\times 9\times 8\times 7\times 1 \\ &= \boxed{2520}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 10 choose 2 * 8 choose 3"
shows  "n = 2520"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Calculate the value of $n$ when $n = {10 \choose 2} \cdot {8 \choose 3}$. The final answer is $2520$.
